GENETICS 

Mendel is best known for his studies of the pea plant.

Mendel's first law (law of segregation) 

It states that a pair of genes (factor) is separated or segregated during gamete formation (spores in lower plants) and only one gene of a pair can be represented in a single gamete. 

Mendel's second law (law of independent assortment)

It states that when two or more pairs of genes of contrasting characters are present, each pair is independently inherited. 

The F1 generation refers to the first filial generation. Filial generations are the nomenclature given to subsequent sets of offspring from controlled or observed reproduction. 

The F2 (second filial) generation consists of the offspring from allowing the F1 individuals to interbreed.

The initial generation is given the letter “P” for parental generation

The theory of blending inheritance states that the progeny inherits any characteristic as the average of the parents' values of that characteristic.

Mendelian Genetics could not explain multiple alleles, incomplete dominance, sex-linked characters, co-dominance, linkage, sex determination, polygenic inheritance. Though his theory is the most acceptable but it needed these amendments. Mendel is the father of Genetics.

 

Genes, DNA and Chromosomes

A gene is the basic physical and functional unit of heredity. Genes are made up of DNA bases. Some genes act as instructions to make molecules called proteins. However, many genes do not code for proteins. A DNA consist of many genes that code for different proteins. 

Chromosomes are thread-like structures in which DNA is tightly packaged within the nucleus. DNA is coiled around proteins called histones, which provide the structural support.

A chromosome is made of a very long strand of DNA and contains many genes (hundreds to thousands). The genes on each chromosome are arranged in a sequence, and each gene has a location on the chromosome (called its locus).

Lampbrush chromosomes (LBCs) are transcriptionally active chromosomes found in the germinal vesicle (GV) of large oocytes of many vertebrate and invertebrate animals and also in the giant single-celled alga Acetabularia. Their name stems from their similarity to bottle brushes. Lampbrush chromosome of the early prophase is a bivalent, made up of two conjugating homologues.

Adenosine 5'-triphosphate, or ATP, is the principal molecule for storing and transferring energy in cells. Animals store the energy obtained from the breakdown of food as ATP. Likewise, plants capture and store the energy they derive from light during photosynthesis in ATP molecules.

ADP needs to be converted to ATP for the body use. 

Viruses are the smallest known organisms made of two parts; an outer part is protein and the inner part which is composed of genetic material DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) or RNA (ribonucleic acid). It behaves as both living and non-living organism under different conditions. Once a virus finds itself in a host it replicates within the host by the help of its genetic material. It cannot reproduce outside the host.

 

UNN PUTME Examples

1. Genes are located at the ....

A. chromosome B. Nucleus C. Mitochondria D. ribosome

(A. A chromosome is made of a very long strand of DNA and contains many genes (hundreds to thousands). The genes on each chromosome are arranged in a particular sequence, and each gene has a particular location on the chromosome (called its locus), 2014/2015, no 2)

 

2. All the sons of a colour-blind woman will be colour blind regardless of the state of the father because

A. the egg determines the phenotype of the sons B. sons inherit the sex chromosomes of their mothers C. the father’s sex chromosomes is weaker in sons D. sex-linked traits express dominance in females

(D. sex-linked traits express dominance in females, 2017/2018 II, no 1)

 

3. Lamp brush chromosome occurs in

A. salivary gland B. lymph glands C. cancer cells D. oocytes

(D. Lampbrush chromosomes (LBCs) are transcriptionally active chromosomes found in the germinal vesicle (GV) of large oocytes of many vertebrate and invertebrate animals and also in the giant single-celled alga Acetabularia. Their name stems from their similarity to bottle brushes. Lampbrush chromosome of the early prophase is a bivalent, made up of two conjugating homologues)

 

4. One of these is not amendment of Mendelian genetics

A. multiple alleles B. incomplete dominance C. sex-linked character D. single factor inheritance

(D. Mendelian Genetics could not explain multiple alleles, incomplete dominance, sex-linked characters, co-dominance, linkage, sex determination, polygenic inheritance. Though his theory is the most acceptable but it needed these amendments. He is the father of Genetics, 2005/2006, no 15)

 

5. The unit of heredity is

A. Chromosome B. Gene C. Chromatid D. Centromere

(B. A gene is the basic physical and functional unit of heredity. Genes are made up of DNA bases. Some genes act as instructions to make molecules called proteins, 2011/2012, no 4)

 

6. When two parents are crossed the offspring are referred to as

A. recessives B. test cross C. F1 generation D. F2 generation

(C. The F1 generation refers to the first filial generation. Filial generations are the nomenclature given to subsequent sets of offspring from controlled or observed reproduction. The F2 (second filial) generation consists of the offspring from allowing the F1 individuals to interbreed, 2012/2013, no 3)

 

7. The exchange of genes between homologous chromosomes is called_____

A. test cross B. back cross C. crossing-over D. mutation

(C. Chromosomal crossover, or crossing over, is the exchange of genetic material between two homologous chromosomes non-sister chromatids that results in recombinant chromosomes during sexual reproduction, 2015/2016, no 14)

 

8. A red-coloured flower when crossed with a white-coloured one produced pink flowers. This is an example of_____

9. A. complete dominance B. blending inheritance C. interaction of genes D. black crossing

(B. The theory is that the progeny inherits any characteristic as the average of the parents' values of that characteristic, 2015/2016 II, no 15)

 

JAMB Examples

1. If both parents are heterozygous for a trait, the probability that an offspring will 

be recessive for that trait is

A. ¾ B. ½ C. ¼ D. 1

(C. ¼)

 

2. The chromosome number of a cell before and after the process of meiosis is conventionally represented as

A. 2n → 2n

B. n → n

C. n → 2n

D. 2n → n

(D. 2n → n)

 

3. The number of alleles controlling blood groups in humans

A. 3 B. 4 C. 5 D. 2

(A. 3)

 

4. When a colour-blind man marries a carrier woman. What is the probability of their offspring being colour blind?

A. 25% B. 50% C. 75% D. 100%

(B. 50%)

 

5. The immediate product of meiosis in flowering plants is the 

A. sporophyte B. gametophyte C. zygote D. pollen grains

(D. pollen grains)

 

6. A man who is heterozygous for the disease haemophilia marries a woman who is double recessive for haemophilia. What percentage of their offspring would have the disease? 

A. 0% B. 25% C. 50% D. 75%

(C. 50%)

 

7. An accurate identification of a rapist can 

be carried out by it conducting a

A. RNA analysis B. DNA analysis C. blood group test D. behavioural traits test

(B. DNA analysis)
